metadata.title: Molecular regulation of nano-structured solid-state AZO-SWCNTs assembly film for the high-energy and short-term solar thermal storage

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/solmat
Molecular regulation of nano-structured solid-state AZO-SWCNTs assembly film for the high-energy and short-term solar thermal storage Yan Jianga, Jin Huanga,b,⁎, Wei Fengc, Xi Zhaod, Ting Wanga, Chunhai Lie, Wen Luoa,f,⁎
a School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China b School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Zhaoqing University, Zhaoqing 526061, China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China d School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China eGuangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming 525000, China fDepartment of Chemistry, University of Texas Rio Grande Valley, 1201 West University Drive, Edinburg 78539, USA
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Reversible isomerization Solar thermal fuels Gravimetric energy density Half-lifetime Solid-state film
A B S T R A C T
A closed-cycle system by storing and releasing solar energy without additional interchange of material is crucial for future high global energy demands. Here, we presented a solid-state molecular solar thermal fuels (STFs) composed of single-walled carbon nanotubes and azobenzene with push-pull electron structure (AZO-SWCNTs) employing the direct Friedel-crafts acylation reaction. This kind of STFs reveals the highest gravimetric energy density of 80.7Wh kg−1 and power density of 292W kg−1 in AZO-CNTs STFs system with extended half-lifetime and excellent photochemical cycling stability. Moreover, the high performance and closed cycle of storage and heat release of the solid-state STFs assembly film were also investigated. The STFs shows relatively a high energy storage efficiency (12.4%) and a solar energy storage efficiency (0.25%) with a maximum temperature difference of 10 °C. This kind of solid-state STFs film exhibits a great potency in high-energy and short-term solar energy thermal storage.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With sharply increasing energy demand in modern society, solar energy high-efficiency storage is a significantly important challenge [1]. Solar energy storage is mainly divided into physical energy storage including sensible and latent heat storage, and chemical energy storage including thermochemical and photochemical energy storage [2–7]. Among these technologies, photochemical energy storage is particularly more attractive because of high-energy and stable solar storage, which dose not require physical separation of substances and then not require storage of them in different containers in comparison to thermochemical energy storage. The concept of closed-cycle solar thermal fuels (STFs), a promising technology of storing solar energy, can reversibly store solar energy in chemical bonds and then release it as heat based on the reversible molecular isomerization without the emission of green-house gas [8]. There are various photo-response molecular systems for the STFs, especially the norbornadiene [9,10], anthracene [11], stilbene [12], fulvalene diruthenium [13] and azobenzene [14]. Thereinto, the azobenzene molecules (AZO) with unique cycling stability, tunable absorption region and molecular interactions are an ideal
candidate for STFs [14–16], which can be also applied in other energy storage fields, such as rapid windshield de-icing [17], optically-controlled phase change materials [18] and self-switching smart windows [19].
However, single AZO molecule remains great challenges to meet a high storage capacity and a long half-lifetime (τ1/2) because of the low isomerization enthalpy (ΔH) and activation barrier (Ea) for cis-to-trans isomerization, respectively [20]. For this reason, a possible solution is the employment of push-pull electronic structure [21,22] or multiortho- substituted groups [23–25] in the molecular design to increase the ΔH or Ea, but it is still difficult to improve the ΔH and Ea at the same time by controlling the molecular structure of azobenzene. Fortunately, another approach is that a templated architecture can increase both the ΔH and Ea by enhanced intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance. For the past few years, AZO hybrids functioned with polymers have been reported for the photo-thermal storage with favorable halflifetime for daily-use solar energy storage [26–28]. However, the gravimetric energy density of the AZO-polymer is still relatively low that limited the further application. Moreover, a variety of templated architectures containing carbon nanomaterials have been tried to

further improve the ΔH and Ea, such as carbon nanotube [22,29] and graphene [8,30]. In consequence, these AZO-carbon STFs exhibited much higher storage capacity and longer half-lifetime. While AZOgraphene (AZO-G) hybrids can store large isomerization enthalpies, long-term UV radiation (at least several hours) of AZO-G STFs is need for storing energy, resulting in an inefficient absorption ability and a low transformation ratio.
In view of this, carbon nanotubes have become a better candidate for solar thermal storage. Several studies have focused on increasing storage capacity and half-lifetime of AZO-carbon nanotubes (AZOCNTs). Grossman et al. [29] prepared AZO-single wall carbon nanotubes (AZO-SWCNTs) without push-pull electronic structure and hydrogen bonding regulation. The results indicated AZO-SWCNTs increase both the amount of energy stored per AZO molecule by more than 30% (56Wh kg−1) and the storage τ1/2 (33 h) by orders of magnitude owing to the intermolecular interactions and the bundling effect in the solid compared with the single azobenzene molecule, which can be applied as short-term daily-use STFs. Our group also reported a short-term daily-use STFs with a relatively high gravimetric energy density to 77Wh kg−1 and half-lifetime of 14 h increased 92.5% and 2 orders of magnitude relative to azobenzene composed of push-pull electronic structure molecule and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (AZOMWCNTs) [22]. However, the existing energy density of AZO-CNTs STFs is still limited the future application.
In addition, the AZO-CNTs STFs generally exist as powder and require dilution with organic solvents to store energy, limiting the practical application. The solid-state film is more useful than powder for practical STF large-scale application, or thermochromic display application [31]. The templated structure enables AZO to form a close packed orderly architecture in solid-state that favors intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance. Grossman [26,32] first reported and developed the solid-state STF films. Despite a low gravimetric energy density, the uniform films show great photo-thermal performance for solar energy storage and conversion. It should be noted that there is a difference in temperature change (DT) up to 10 °C by controlling the heat release process. Feng [8,31] focused on the design and application of reduced graphene oxide-Azo (RGO-Azo) film with high gravimetric energy density and a DT of over 10 °C. In conclusion, although the CNTs is considered as a good template, few studies have deeply investigated the AZO-CNT film for STFs application, especially AZO-SWCNTs film.
Herein, an effective approach to synthesize a short-term daily-use STFs film with push-pull electronic structure AZO/SWCNTs hybrids is employed (Fig. 1). The relatively high functional density and bundling effect enhance the intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance from the same or neighboring SWCNTs. The AZO-SWCNTs shows a remarkably improvement of gravimetric energy density and τ1/2 with excellent cycling performance. Moreover, the photo-thermal performance and controlled energy storage of the uniform STFs film are further analyzed. This class of nano-structured solid-state STFs presents an advantageous performance for efficient and reversible short-term solar energy storage.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of AZO molecule
sections.text: Here, 4-(4-hydroxphenylazo) benzoic acid (AZO) with push-pull electronic structure was designed to increase its molecular storage density [21,22]. All the main materials are supplied by Aldrich and used as received, unless otherwise mentioned. The AZO molecule was synthesized by a diazo coupling reaction [33] with some modifications. Typically, 4-aminobenzoic acid (1.37 g, 0.01mol), NaNO2 (0.69 g, 0.01mol) were dissolved in 40mL distilled water, and the mixture was added into HCl solution (40mL, 1mol L−1) in ice bath for diazotization. The diazonium salt solution was slowly added into a 40mL suspension of phenol (0.94 g, 0.01mol) and sodium hydroxide (0.4 g, 0.01mol). The mixture was reacted for 2 h with pH 8–9 under the protection of argon in ice bath, then acidified to pH 6 kept for 30min. After that, the solid precipitate was washed with distilled water to obtain crude product. The final AZO molecule was collected after recrystallization and dried under vacuum (yield 57%). 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO-d6, δ): 13.15(s, 1 H, -COOH), 10.45(s, 1H, -OH), 8.11(d, 2H, Ar–H), 7.89(d, 2H, Ar–H), 7.83(d, 2H, Ar–H), 6.97(d, 2H, Ar–H).

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of AZO-SWCNTs powder/film
sections.text:
The AZO-SWCNTs was prepared by direct Friedel-crafts acylation reaction [34] with some modifications. Typically, the mixture of AZO (1.94 g), SWCNTs (24mg), polyphosphoric acid (PPA, 10 g) and phosphorous pentoxide (P2O5, 2.5 g) was reacted for 72 h in oil bath
(140 °C) under nitrogen condition. After cooling down to room temperature, the distilled water was added while stirring to obtain a uniform suspension. The final AZO-SWCNTs powder was collected after filtration, washing with diluted ammonia, distilled water and ethanol, and then freeze-drying (Fig. S1a). The self-supported AZO-SWCNTs film (Fig. S1b) was fabricated after ultrasonication, vacuum filtration and drying in vacuum oven based on a 0.5mgmL−1 suspension in dimethylformamide (DMF).

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterizations
sections.text:
High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM; JEM2100F, Jeol, Japan) and scanning electronic microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800) were employed to investigate the morphologies. Conventional optical microscope was used to obtain film photograph. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra recorded on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a KBr disk at room temperature, 1H NMR spectra using a Bruker AVANCE III 400MHz Superconducting Fourier with trimethylsilyl as an internal standard and UV Laser Raman Spectroscopy (LabRAM HR 800; HORIBA Jobin Yvon; France) using a laser wavelength of 633 nm were applied to test the chemical structures. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Escalab 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) was used to identify the composition. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was supported by using a Thermo gravimetric Analyzer Instrument (NETZSCHSTA 449 C). The samples were heated from 30 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °Cmin−1 in an aluminium crucible under 50mLmin−1 of nitrogen purging. Time-evolved UV–Vis absorption spectra of AZO and AZO-SWCNTs in ethanol solution using 1 cm pathlength quartz cuvettes were recorded by a UV–Vis spectrophotometer (UV2450, Shimadzu, Japan) with a light intensity of 30mW cm−2.
The gravimetric energy density of AZO molecule and AZO-SWCNTs were determined using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC; Q2000 V24.10 Build 122; America) by an average value of three measurements. The typical DSC measured process is shown as the Ref. [22]. Samples were analyzed by DSC using the following method: equilibration at 0 °C heating to 150 °C at 5 °Cmin−1 for calculating the heat in reversion from cis to trans isomer; cooling down to 0 °C at 5 °Cmin−1 and re-heating to 150 °C at 5 °Cmin−1 as a comparison. The macroscopic heat release process of the irradiated and unirradiated AZO-SWCNTs films on heating stage was monitored with a thermal imager (FLUKE TiX640). The typical process is shown as following: the AZO-SWCNTs film was cut into two parts, then one part was irradiated with the UV light （365 nm） for 12 h and the other part kept in darkness. After, the two parts were heated on the surface of a heating stage (heating to 150 °C at 10 °Cmin−1; hold at 150 °C for 15min).

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphological properties
sections.text: To observe the changes of morphologies after functionalization, TEM was carried out for SWCNTs and AZO-SWCNTs in ethyl alcohol. As shown in Fig. 2a inset, the isolated SWCNTs can be obviously observed with a diameter about 2 nm. However, most SWCNTs are easy to form the ropes consist of several SWCNTs bundling together (Fig. 2a) [35], which is also can be observed by SEM in the solid state (Fig. S2). The bundling effect (Fig. S3) is beneficial to increase intermolecular interactions of AZO-SWCNTs in solid state compared to solution state owing to the decreased intermolecular distance [29]. From Fig. 2b, a clear layer covering the surface of SWCNTs after covalent functionalization (see the green part) indicates that the AZO molecules were bound on the surface because of the high functional density [36–38].

sections.heading: 3.2. Chemical properties
sections.text:
The covalent attachment of AZO on SWCNTs was characterized using FT-IR, XPS and Raman spectra. Compared to SWCNTs, the FT-IR spectrum of AZO-SWCNTs (Fig. 3a) shows the characteristic peaks of -N=N- group and C˭O stretching vibration of AZO at 1403 cm−1 and 1637 cm−1. And it can be found that there is a red-shift of the C˭O stretching vibration owing to the breaking of the molecular push-pull electronic structure [39].
Besides, the XPS spectrum was also applied to demonstrate the covalent bond. Different from SWCNTs, the new peak of nitrogen element in XPS (Fig. 3b) and new band at 400.1 eV in the N1s region of AZO-SWCNTs (Fig. 3c) can be attributed to the overlap of N=N and NC [40], exhibiting the existence of the AZO. Moreover, the C1s region of AZO-SWCNTs (Fig. 3d) shows only one new C-C˭O band at 286.6 eV without the O-C˭O band at 290.3 eV [41], indicating the carboxyl groups are reacted in chemical reaction compared to SWCNTs (Fig. S4). The above results indicate that AZO are covalently grafted on the SWCNTs.
Furthermore, the chemical changes between AZO and SWCNTs can be further proved by Raman spectrum. As shown in Fig. 3e, the SWCNTs exhibits a radial breathing mode (RBM), a D-band and a Gband. After functionalization, it shows an increasing intensity ratio of ID/IG, indicating the increased defects in the CNTs [42,43]. This is because of the introduction of AZO to the surface of SWCNTs at a high functional density, resulting in part sp2-hybridized carbon transfer to sp3-hybridized carbon [43]. It is consistent with the up-shift (about 6 cm−1) phenomenon of the RBM frequency (Fig. 3f) after functionalization [44,45]. The above data also demonstrate that the AZO molecules are covalently grafted onto the SWCNTs.
High functional density is very significant to improve the storage
capacity and half-lifetime. The final functional density of AZO-SWCNTs is shown in Table S1 according to the TGA (Fig. S5) and XPS data (Fig. 3b), respectively. The SWCNTs shows a lower weight loss with a good thermal stability because of the steady carbon conjugated structure. The AZO molecule starts to decompose at 230 °C with a large weight decreases at 250 °C. And the AZO-SWCNTs shows a high weight loss attributed to the decomposition of AZO on the SWCNTs. According to the Equation S1 [46], the functional density could be calculated as 1:31. It means that one AZO molecule is approximately supported by per 31 carbon atoms, which is higher than most previous reports [47–49]. In addition, the similar functional density also could be estimated based on the atomic percentage of varying carbon and emerging
nitrogen [50]. This high functional density is conducive to enhance the intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance between adjacent AZO on the same and neighboring SWCNTs owing to the bundling effect in solid state, which can be observed by SEM images (Fig. S2). This is of great importance to obtain the high-energy and controllable releasing for the solid-state energy storage.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photo-isomerization and reversion performances
sections.text:
The photo-isomerization behavior and revision process of AZO and AZO-SWCNTs in ethanol solution (15mg L−1) were investigated by UV–Vis absorption spectra at 25 °C. As shown in Fig. 4, the absorption
peak of AZO-SWCNTs at 354 nm is attributed to the π-π* transition of trans-isomer. It shows a blue shift compared to AZO (359 nm, Fig. S6) owing to the breaking of push-pull electronic interaction [51,52].
Upon irradiated at 365 nm UV light, the AZO-SWCNTs and AZO show a constant decrease in the intensity of π-π* transition until reaching photo-stationary state (PSS) because of the trans-to-cis isomerization (Fig. 4a and Fig. S6a). In this process, the energy can be stored in the chemical bond in metastable cis structure. After that, the stored energy can be later released from metastable cis state to stable trans state under darkness or at higher temperature. The AZO-SWCNTs shows a much slower complete reconversion with 72 h while the AZO just needs 10min under darkness (Fig. 4b and Fig. S6b). This is because the AZO molecules on SWCNTs are limited by the enhanced intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance. According to the Equation S2 [30], the Ea of the cis-AZO on SWCNTs is 1.05 eV while single cisAZO is 0.89 eV, resulting in a significant increase in τ1/2 (about 16 h) compared to the AZO (just 150 s). We also investigated the UV–Vis absorption of the AZO-SWCNTs film (Fig. S7), revealing the consistent variation with AZO-SWCNTs in the solution. The π-π* transition peak decreases after UV irradiation, while the peak increases to the original absorption after heat release.
The cis-to-trans isomerization degree of the AZO-SWCNTs is of importance for high-energy solar thermal storage, which can be acquired by Equation S3 [8]. The isomerization degree of AZO-SWCNTs is about 64%, which is compatible with the published literatures (60% ~ 77%) [8,17,28–30]. And the first-order rate constant of the reversion of cisrich AZO-SWCNTs (κrev (in dark) = 9.32× 10−6 s−1) according to Equation S4 [8] is four orders of magnitude lower than that of AZO (4.15×10−2 s−1). At a higher temperature (60 °C), this reversion process can be accelerated, demonstrating a shorter τ1/2 of 20min (Fig. 4c). And from Fig. 4d, the first-order rate constant of AZO-
SWCNTs at 60 °C is 6.01×10−4 s−1 (Fig. 4d), which is two orders of magnitude higher than that in dark at 25 °C. The results exhibit the STFs has great potential in controllable energy releasing.
We also investigated the photochemical cycling stability in the solution and solid-state film by repeatedly energy storing and releasing. Trans-to-cis-to-trans isomerization of the AZO-SWCNTs was induced alternately by UV light and completely restored at 60 °C (Fig. S8a-b). The results indicate the AZO-SWCNTs STFs in the solution and solidstate film both show excellent cycling stability for 30 and 15 cycles without the obvious photo degradation, which is similarly to the result of AZO molecule in Fig. S8c. This excellent cycling stability is very important for the future STFs application.

sections.heading: 3.4. Energy storage capacity and power density
sections.text:
The energy storage capacity is another radical parameter for practical application. The solar energy is stored within rearranged chemical bonds and released as heat later in the AZO-SWCNTs STFs based on the reversible photo-isomerization. The heat released from AZO-SWCNTs and AZO powder in solution, and AZO-SWCNTs film by UV light-irradiated were measured by DSC based on heat-induced cis-to-trans isomerization [29]. The heat releasing process of the cis-rich state AZOSWCNTs powder in solution, AZO-SWCNTs film and AZO powder in solution were illustrated in Fig. 5 and Fig. S9. All the cis-rich state samples did not decompose at the full scanning temperature range based on TGA data (Fig. S5). As shown in Fig. 5a, a distinct broad exothermic heat flow over 37–120 °C was observed for the AZOSWCNTs powder during the first heating-cooling segment and no heat flow in the second segment. Similar phenomenon can be also observed in the DSC curve of AZO molecule (Fig. S9) and AZO-SWCNTs film (Fig. 5b). The above results indicate that the heat flow in first heating
was stored energy from the light and was released based on the heatinduced cis-to-trans isomerization. Gravimetric energy density of the AZO-SWCNTs powder, AZO-SWCNTs film and AZO powder can be calculated by the integration of exothermic heat flow. Compared to the single AZO (39Wh kg−1), the AZO-SWCNTs powder/film reveal a much higher gravimetric energy density up to 80.7Wh kg−1/60.4Wh kg−1, which are the highest in existing AZO-CNTs STFs system [22,29]. The encouraging result is mainly owing to the obviously enhanced intermolecular interactions and steric hindrance based on the high functional density [53,54] and bundling effect [29,54], which generate the prominent increase of the ΔH and Ea. Moreover, the energy storage efficiency irradiating at 365 nm is estimated to be 12.4% according to Equation S5 [29], which is comparable to recent reports [22,29]. The solar energy storage efficiency under AM1.5 irradiation is also estimated to be 0.25% (Equation S6 [29]). Although the solar energy storage efficiency is significantly lower than that of solar cells, it is on a par with existing AZO-based STFs [29,51] and typical photosynthesis [55]. This comparatively low solar energy storage efficiency is a result of the different solar storage mechanism. For STFs the energy is stored in the chemical bond due to the rearrangement of molecular structure while a solar cell converts the energy of light directly into electricity by the photovoltaic effect [56].
Due to sensitivity of effective volume to solution condition, it is necessary to obtain the power density (PD). According to Equation S7 [8], the PD of the AZO-SWCNTs powder are 292W kg−1. Compared to the powder, the AZO-SWCNTs film (233W kg−1) shows a 25% decrease owing to the lower isomerization degree arising from the steric hindrance the solid-state film compared to that of the powder in the solution, which can be supported by the Fig. S7. Both of power density of AZO-SWCNTs powder in solution and solid-state AZO-SWCNTs film is higher than the existing AZO-CNTs STFs [29].

sections.heading: 3.5. Macroscopic heat release
sections.text:
It is necessary to prepare the STFs film to macroscopic heat release and large-scale application. The AZO-SWCNTs hybrid was added into the DMF solution (0.5mgmL−1) by ultrasonication for 2 h to obtain a homogeneously dispersion. The self-supported film was acquired after filtrating and drying in vacuum. Optical microscope image and crosssectional SEM image show the film was uniform (Fig. 6a) with a thickness of ~30 µm (Fig. 6b), which is comparable to the recent studies [8,26].
The macroscopic heat release of AZO-SWCNTs film on heating stage was investigated by a thermal imager. The film was cut into two parts, then one part was irradiated with UV light (365 nm) for 12 h and another part kept in dark. Subsequently, two parts were heated on a heating stage. Fig. 7a-b illustrate the surface temperature profile of the AZO-SWCNTs films, showing the color changes represent corresponding temperature changes. It can be seen that the temperature of irradiated film is obvious higher than the unirradiated film, and there is no significant change in DT during the heat release (Fig. 7b) for the unirradiated film, indicating that the DT was caused by the heat release from cis-to-trans isomerization rather than other effects [8].
To further understand the heat release process, the average temperature plot of the irradiated and unirradiated films was obtained. As shown in Fig. 7c, the heating process can be divided into pre-heating, heat release process, constant temperature process. The DT between the two films is invariant in the first and third stages, while the irradiated film temperature sharply increase in the second stage, consistent with the DSC result of the AZO-SWCNTs film. Moreover, the maximum DT between the two films is ~10 °C from the Fig. 7d due to the heat release from cis-to-trans isomerization. The results indicate that this uniform STF film can be applied to the large-scale solar energy thermal fuels.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: A novel AZO-SWCNTs hybrid with push-pull electronic structure was successfully synthesized via an effective covalent method. The relatively high functional density and bundling effect in the solid state can improved the intermolecular interactions on the same and/or neighboring nanotube [29,53], resulting in a highest gravimetric energy density (80.7Wh kg−1) and a relatively higher power density of 292W kg−1 in the AZO-CNTs STFs system. Simultaneously, the AZOSWCNTs shows ultrastable and reusable energy storage ability and increased half-lifetime (16 h). Moreover, the uniform AZO-SWCNTs film was prepared and showed similar photo-thermal performance with a maximum DT of 10 °C. Furthermore, the STFs shows the energy storage efficiency and solar energy storage efficiency of 12.4% and 0.25%, respectively. This class of nano-structured hybrids exhibits a great prospect as an ideal candidate for the high-energy and short-term solar thermal fuels.

metadata.abstractText: A closed-cycle system by storing and releasing solar energy without additional interchange of material is crucial for future high global energy demands. Here, we presented a solid-state molecular solar thermal fuels (STFs) composed of single-walled carbon nanotubes and azobenzene with push-pull electron structure (AZO-SWCNTs) employing the direct Friedel-crafts acylation reaction. This kind of STFs reveals the highest gravimetric energy density of 80.7Wh kg and power density of 292W kg in AZO-CNTs STFs system with extended half-lifetime and excellent photochemical cycling stability. Moreover, the high performance and closed cycle of storage and heat release of the solid-state STFs assembly film were also investigated. The STFs shows relatively a high energy storage efficiency (12.4%) and a solar energy storage efficiency (0.25%) with a maximum temperature difference of 10 °C. This kind of solid-state STFs film exhibits a great potency in high-energy and short-term solar energy
